PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person responding to this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. It's best to answer all questions, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this questionnaire, but are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A TOTAL OF 30 QUESTIONS AS TO THE PERSON'S EXPERIENCES IN THE PIONEER YEARS

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived through it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have been added to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so do not worry about leaving blank spaces. If you feel able to give details, or describe particular experiences, please try to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914. It may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years when they lived in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Plots: What Did Western Canada's Pioneer Settlers Do?", is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and will be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be sent at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Branch Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

1. Your full name: T. H. O. M. A. S.

2. Your address: 489-4th St., Lloydminster.

3. Date of birth: 1875.

4. What was your father's name and occupation? John Parr (Canadian).

5. What was your mother's name? Anna Parr (Canadian).

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? April 1903.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.). 38 years.

9. That were your reasons for coming West?

I always had a wish to come since I was a young boy & seeing in the papers that there was a great opportunity for me.

Through reading about it
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Why thought I was crazy

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends etc.)?

With a party

13. What kind of transportation did you use?

Horace & wagon

14. What accidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way! meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

We came up from Saskatoon in the early morning over a very faint trail; we very often got bogged with the sloughs and had to unload the wagons and try wagons with a logging chain attached to the front end of the load and again that no good as sometimes got hung up along then have would jamb up and stop each other out.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the camp that Mr. Barr had established near the present site of the town.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

First 16-mile land of Okanagan & Wm.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Iowa

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was employed in the P.C. in London after I came out here I took up a homestead.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Why thought I was crazy

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, etc.)?

With a party

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Horsecar & wagon

14. What incidents or the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way? Meetings with Indians? Adventures on the journey? Accidents or other excitement etc.)

We came up from Saskatoon in the early spring over a very faint trail; we very often got bogged in the sloughs and had to unload the wagons and go back out via the grade with a logging chain attached to the front of the load to keep it going. That was quite an adventure.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Mr. Smith's place near the present site of Regina.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Regina

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I've

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was employed in the P.C. in London after I came out here I took up a farmstead.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About every few weeks or so.
